segment.source: Display points of interest (POI) on a map
segment.target: Display points of interest (POI) on a map

segment.source: Add points of interest (POI) to a map using pushpins, images, shapes, and XAML UI elements.
segment.target: Add points of interest (POI) to a map using pushpins, images, shapes, and XAML UI elements.

segment.source: Display points of interest (POI) on a map
segment.target: Display points of interest (POI) on a map

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Add points of interest (POI) to a map using pushpins, images, shapes, and XAML UI elements.
segment.target: Add points of interest (POI) to a map using pushpins, images, shapes, and XAML UI elements.

segment.source: A POI is a specific point on the map that represents something of interest.
segment.target: A POI is a specific point on the map that represents something of interest.

segment.source: For example, the location of a business, city, or friend.
segment.target: For example, the location of a business, city, or friend.

segment.source: Tip To learn more about displaying POI on your app, download the following sample from the Windows-universal-samples repo on GitHub.
segment.target: Tip To learn more about displaying POI on your app, download the following sample from the Windows-universal-samples repo on GitHub.

segment.source: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) map sample
segment.target: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) map sample

segment.source: Display pushpins, images, and shapes on the map by adding MapIcon, MapPolygon, and MapPolyline objects to the MapElements collection of the map control.
segment.target: Display pushpins, images, and shapes on the map by adding MapIcon, MapPolygon, and MapPolyline objects to the MapElements collection of the map control.

segment.source: Use data binding or add items programmatically; you can't bind to the MapElements collection declaratively in your XAML markup.
segment.target: Use data binding or add items programmatically; you can't bind to the MapElements collection declaratively in your XAML markup.

segment.source: Display XAML user interface elements such as a Button, a HyperlinkButton, or a TextBlock on the map by adding them as Children of the MapControl.
segment.target: Display XAML user interface elements such as a Button, a HyperlinkButton, or a TextBlock on the map by adding them as Children of the MapControl.

segment.source: You can also add them to the MapItemsControl, or bind the MapItemsControl to a collection of items.
segment.target: You can also add them to the MapItemsControl, or bind the MapItemsControl to a collection of items.

segment.source: In summary:
segment.target: In summary:

segment.source: Add a MapIcon to the map to display an image such as a pushpin with optional text.
segment.target: Add a MapIcon to the map to display an image such as a pushpin with optional text.

segment.source: Add a MapPolygon to the map to display a multi-point shape.
segment.target: Add a MapPolygon to the map to display a multi-point shape.

segment.source: Add a MapPolyline to the map to display lines on the map.
segment.target: Add a MapPolyline to the map to display lines on the map.

segment.source: Add XAML to the map to display custom UI elements.
segment.target: Add XAML to the map to display custom UI elements.

segment.source: If you have a large number of elements to place on the map, consider overlaying tiled images on the map.
segment.target: If you have a large number of elements to place on the map, consider overlaying tiled images on the map.

segment.source: To display roads on the map, see Display routes and directions.
segment.target: To display roads on the map, see Display routes and directions.

segment.source: Add a MapIcon
segment.target: Add a MapIcon

segment.source: Display an image such a pushpin, with optional text, on the map by using the MapIcon class.
segment.target: Display an image such a pushpin, with optional text, on the map by using the MapIcon class.

segment.source: You can accept the default image or provide a custom image by using the Image property.
segment.target: You can accept the default image or provide a custom image by using the Image property.

segment.source: The following image displays the default image for a MapIcon with no value specified for the Title property, with a short title, with a long title, and with a very long title.
segment.target: The following image displays the default image for a MapIcon with no value specified for the Title property, with a short title, with a long title, and with a very long title.

segment.source: sample mapicon with titles of different lengths.
segment.target: sample mapicon with titles of different lengths.

segment.source: The following example shows a map of the city of Seattle and adds a MapIcon with the default image and an optional title to indicate the location of the Space Needle.
segment.target: The following example shows a map of the city of Seattle and adds a MapIcon with the default image and an optional title to indicate the location of the Space Needle.

segment.source: It also centers the map over the icon and zooms in.
segment.target: It also centers the map over the icon and zooms in.

segment.source: For general info about using the map control, see Display maps with 2D, 3D, and Streetside views.
segment.target: For general info about using the map control, see Display maps with 2D, 3D, and Streetside views.

segment.source: This example displays the following POI on the map (the default image in the center).
segment.target: This example displays the following POI on the map (the default image in the center).

segment.source: map with mapicon
segment.target: map with mapicon

segment.source: The following line of code displays the MapIcon with a custom image saved in the Assets folder of the project.
segment.target: The following line of code displays the MapIcon with a custom image saved in the Assets folder of the project.

segment.source: The Image property of the MapIcon expects a value of type RandomAccessStreamReference.
segment.target: The Image property of the MapIcon expects a value of type RandomAccessStreamReference.

segment.source: This type requires a using statement for the Windows.Storage.Streams namespace.
segment.target: This type requires a using statement for the Windows.Storage.Streams namespace.

segment.source: Tip If you use the same image for multiple map icons, declare the RandomAccessStreamReference at the page or app level for the best performance.
segment.target: Tip If you use the same image for multiple map icons, declare the RandomAccessStreamReference at the page or app level for the best performance.

segment.source: Keep these considerations in mind when working with the MapIcon class:
segment.target: Keep these considerations in mind when working with the MapIcon class:

segment.source: The Image property supports a maximum image size of 2048×2048 pixels.
segment.target: The Image property supports a maximum image size of 2048×2048 pixels.

segment.source: By default, the map icon's image is not guaranteed to be shown.
segment.target: By default, the map icon's image is not guaranteed to be shown.

segment.source: It may be hidden when it obscures other elements or labels on the map.
segment.target: It may be hidden when it obscures other elements or labels on the map.

segment.source: To keep it visible, set the map icon's CollisionBehaviorDesired property to MapElementCollisionBehavior.RemainVisible.
segment.target: To keep it visible, set the map icon's CollisionBehaviorDesired property to MapElementCollisionBehavior.RemainVisible.

segment.source: The optional Title of the MapIcon is not guaranteed to be shown.
segment.target: The optional Title of the MapIcon is not guaranteed to be shown.

segment.source: If you don't see the text, zoom out by decreasing the value of the ZoomLevel property of the MapControl.
segment.target: If you don't see the text, zoom out by decreasing the value of the ZoomLevel property of the MapControl.

segment.source: When you display a MapIcon image that points to a specific location on the map - for example, a pushpin or an arrow - consider setting the value of the NormalizedAnchorPoint property to the approximate location of the pointer on the image.
segment.target: When you display a MapIcon image that points to a specific location on the map - for example, a pushpin or an arrow - consider setting the value of the NormalizedAnchorPoint property to the approximate location of the pointer on the image.

segment.source: If you leave the value of NormalizedAnchorPoint at its default value of (0, 0), which represents the upper left corner of the image, changes in the ZoomLevel of the map may leave the image pointing to a different location.
segment.target: If you leave the value of NormalizedAnchorPoint at its default value of (0, 0), which represents the upper left corner of the image, changes in the ZoomLevel of the map may leave the image pointing to a different location.

segment.source: Add a MapPolygon
segment.target: Add a MapPolygon

segment.source: Display a multi-point shape on the map by using the MapPolygon class.
segment.target: Display a multi-point shape on the map by using the MapPolygon class.

segment.source: The following example, from the UWP map sample, displays a red box with blue border on the map.
segment.target: The following example, from the UWP map sample, displays a red box with blue border on the map.

segment.source: Add a MapPolyline
segment.target: Add a MapPolyline

segment.source: Display a line on the map by using the MapPolyline class.
segment.target: Display a line on the map by using the MapPolyline class.

segment.source: The following example, from the UWP map sample, displays a dashed line on the map.
segment.target: The following example, from the UWP map sample, displays a dashed line on the map.

segment.source: Add XAML
segment.target: Add XAML

segment.source: Display custom UI elements on the map using XAML.
segment.target: Display custom UI elements on the map using XAML.

segment.source: Position XAML on the map by specifying the location and normalized anchor point of the XAML.
segment.target: Position XAML on the map by specifying the location and normalized anchor point of the XAML.

segment.source: Set the location on the map where the XAML is placed by calling SetLocation.
segment.target: Set the location on the map where the XAML is placed by calling SetLocation.

segment.source: Set the relative location on the XAML that corresponds to the specified location by calling SetNormalizedAnchorPoint.
segment.target: Set the relative location on the XAML that corresponds to the specified location by calling SetNormalizedAnchorPoint.

segment.source: The following example shows a map of the city of Seattle and adds a XAML Border control to indicate the location of the Space Needle.
segment.target: The following example shows a map of the city of Seattle and adds a XAML Border control to indicate the location of the Space Needle.

segment.source: It also centers the map over the area and zooms in.
segment.target: It also centers the map over the area and zooms in.

segment.source: For general info about using the map control, see Display maps with 2D, 3D, and Streetside views.
segment.target: For general info about using the map control, see Display maps with 2D, 3D, and Streetside views.

segment.source: This example displays a blue border on the map.
segment.target: This example displays a blue border on the map.

segment.source: The next examples show how to add XAML UI elements directly in the XAML markup of the page using data binding.
segment.target: The next examples show how to add XAML UI elements directly in the XAML markup of the page using data binding.

segment.source: As with other XAML elements that display content, Children is the default content property of the MapControl and does not have to be specified explicitly in XAML markup.
segment.target: As with other XAML elements that display content, Children is the default content property of the MapControl and does not have to be specified explicitly in XAML markup.

segment.source: This example shows how to display two XAML controls as implicit children of the MapControl.
segment.target: This example shows how to display two XAML controls as implicit children of the MapControl.

segment.source: This example shows how to display two XAML controls contained within a MapItemsControl.
segment.target: This example shows how to display two XAML controls contained within a MapItemsControl.

segment.source: This example displays a collection of XAML elements bound to a MapItemsControl.
segment.target: This example displays a collection of XAML elements bound to a MapItemsControl.
